Amazing, right?  Not exactly.  I got back home and couldn't do anything over wifi.  The next morning I got to speak to a tech  right away but no solution.  The next level tech told me he also lived outside of cell area and used wifi and knew the problem.  Guess what, I had to go back to the tower to get a strong LTE signal to activate wifi.  The phone works fine now and I'm very happy with it.  KISS gets good marks and Verizon needs to know some people don't have cell service at their home.

CommentsTitle: A rocky start -- but then just fine
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 16, 2020
CommentsContent: I purchased this iPhone 8 (with the Renewed Premium Guarantee) for my daughter.  It arrived in excellent condition.  However, the first day she had it, the phone would crash and restart when the battery reached about 40%.  This happened again over the next couple days.  I went into the battery settings (see attached screen shot) and found that the battery was seriously degraded, even though it was supposed to be in "similar to new" condition with a guaranteed capacity of at least 90%.  So I called Amazon Customer Support for a replacement phone.  It was a cumbersome process.  The Amazon representative had to contact Apple, and he and I were on hold with Apple for about 20 minutes.  When the Apple representative got on the line, the Amazon rep left the call.  The Apple rep remotely ran battery diagnostics and confirmed that the battery was failing.  She then told me the phone was out of warranty and wanted to quote out-of-warranty pricing to me for a new battery.  I objected, stating that Amazon was guaranteeing this phone for a year and wondering why I had to pay for anything at this point.  She then had to talk with her manager, and again I was on hold for several minutes.  She came back and said that I would have to talk with Amazon about the phone.  So I took the case number she gave and called Amazon back.  I was on hold again for a few minutes with Amazon, but when the customer service rep came on the line, I explained the scenario and she took care of the replacement immediately.  I received the new phone the next day.  It arrived in excellent condition and thus far seems to be working perfectly.  Everyone I talked to, both at Amazon and at Apple, was very nice and easy to deal with, it just took a lot of my time to resolve the problem.  All told, I was on the phone for about an hour and five minutes just to get the phone replaced.  I am satisfied with the replacement, I just wish the process would have taken less time.

CommentsTitle: Works well, but far from excellent; battery performance (somewhat?) compromised.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2021
CommentsContent: [Refurbished iPhone 8/64GB. Bought on Jan. 2021.]As the price difference between iPhone 7 and iPhone 8 settled on a rather negligible sum (~ $20), I reconsidered my decision of buying the former (for ~ $160) and thought it to be wiser to obtain the newer model instead. [1]The phone arrived in an Amazon-iPhone-box; the box contained the phone, a booklet, an iPhone needle, a charging cord and a chord-wall connector (these last two were of different colors and do not appear to be of Apple brand). The box came without any earphones/earbuds – unlike what was testified in some of the earlier reviews.Visually, the phone had no scratches or marks – neither on the screen nor anywhere on its body. The entire exterior appeared to be completely indistinguishable (to a naked eye) from that of a new phone. Fingerprint reader functions slightly worse than expected; because the inconvenience is minor (i.e. several attempts being required before successfully unlocking via fingerprint vs. the usual single successful attempt when using the fingerprint verification method on my old phone), the effect of this issue on my opinion of any given phone is not so significant negligible.Thus far, I have been using this phone for about a month and overall it has been working well. However, for me, one of the most important aspects of a phone is, undoubtedly, its battery life; unfortunately, in the case of this phone, the battery life had been somewhat compromised well before its arrival.For comparison: the peak battery performance of this phone --  iPhone 8/64GB -- is 84% upon ~1-2 days of use after purchase (purchase state: refurbished), whereas the peak battery performance of my old phone -- iPhone 6/32GB – is 94% upon ~ 3 years of use after purchase (purchase state: refurbished).An observation to be tested/confirmed: The phone rapidly loses its battery life upon mildly cold weather conditions -- ~  0 – 5 Celsius or  ~ 32 – 41 Fahrenheit -- despite having a rather thick leather cover on and barely being used. A fully charged battery is completely drained in about an hour or less if used under comparable weather conditions. If left unused, the result seems to improve by approximately halving the battery drainage speed, i.e. approximately “doubling the battery life.”The battery life seems to be affected also by the background app activity (but to a much lesser extent if compared the cold weather conditions); however, it is much trickier (than it may initially seem) to control this parameter: The “Background App Refresh” on/off button in the settings menu does not appear to serve its intended purpose – most of the applications continue to function in the background as it pleases them, and, as far as I can tell – (perhaps even completely) independently of any of the phone settings.On the other hand, considering its refurbished state, as an informed buyer I, admittedly, understand what I had signed up for; so, as sad as it can be, it is hardly surprising to discover most of the cons of this phone to be connected to one of the most significant (for me) aspects of the phone – battery life.Finally, taking into account the affordability of the product, its quality, as well as factoring in its projected short life-span in this rapidly innovating world [2.], I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend it to all those in search of a new phone. I will try to update my review as new and significant issues come to light.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[1.] Although it may be worthy to note here that the two phones at the above-mentioned price-points had different memory capacities, I find it difficult to reconcile that a productive person may use/need 32GB or more memory space in a personal phone; thus, any memory capacity succeeding this number is categorized as “a phone with enough space” and treated similarly in terms of that parameter.[2.] Considering the fact that most of us use any given phone for a very short period of time ( I wouldn’t guess it to be longer than 2-3 years), and considering that this already short time period tends to get even shorter over time – due to innovations happening faster and faster and the pace of the change – the development -- accelerating with an overwhelming rate, a phone that already has seen years worth of usage, represents the yesterday (and thus is soon to be replaced with something way more interesting), and costs the fifth of its initial price while functioning essentially only ~ 15% worse than it used to when it was completely new, in my eyes – is a worthy trade.
